case_vignette:
A 20-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type 1 presents with ecchymosis and bullous lesions on his back, posterior legs, and buttocks. He was playing football when he ran into another player and became unconscious. He was immobile in the hospital for 3 days before he regained consciousness. He has about 7 tense blisters with areas of surrounding erythema on the back, buttocks, and posterior thighs. The blisters are not painful, but the surrounding skin is tender to the touch. The patient has a history of recurrent skin infections, including impetigo and folliculitis. The patient's blood pressure is 120/80 mmHg, pulse is 80 beats per minute, and temperature is 98.6°F (37°C). The patient's medical history includes diabetes mellitus type 1, which is well-controlled with insulin therapy. The patient's family history is significant for a history of skin conditions, including eczema and psoriasis. The patient's physical examination reveals ecchymosis and bullous lesions on the back, buttocks, and posterior legs. The patient's laboratory results show a normal complete blood count, normal electrolyte levels, and normal liver function tests. The patient's skin lesions are consistent with a diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid, a chronic autoimmune skin disease characterized by the formation of blisters. The patient's history of recurrent skin infections and family history of skin conditions may suggest a genetic predisposition to skin diseases. The patient's physical examination and laboratory results are consistent with a diagnosis of bullous pemphigoid.

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have ecchymosis and bullous lesions on my back, legs, and buttocks.
When did you first notice these symptoms?
I noticed them after I had an accident playing football and was unconscious for 3 days in the hospital.
Have you been taking any new medications or treatments since your accident?
No, I have not started any new medications or treatments since my accident.
Do you have any previous medical history of bleeding disorders or skin diseases?
I have a history of recurrent skin infections like impetigo and folliculitis, and a family history of skin conditions such as eczema and psoriasis.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatitis herpetiformis
